ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about central banking and monetary policy from a practitioner's perspective -- in particular, the ways in which central banks and monetary authorities globally approach applying the frameworks to promote economic and financial stability in their respective countries. I also learned about the history of central banking, and how idea of monetary policy have evolved over time.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of the course are in the instructor -- Professor Mohan is incredibly knowledgeable about the material, and has spent enough time in his role at various governing institutions as well as at the Reserve Bank of India that his understanding of the concepts of the course shines through. He has decades of experience in the field and aims to impart what he's learned to students, so at times the course can be incredibly dense -- but his teaching makes every discussion worthwhile and intellectually stimulating.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're interested in monetary policy and in particular central banking policy, but you want to learn how central bankers actually think about these issues, you should take this course without hesitation.
